+@register_kl(MultivariateNormal, MultivariateNormal)
+def _kl_multivariatenormal_multivariatenormal(p, q):
+    # From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multivariate_normal_distribution#Kullback%E2%80%93Leibler_divergence
+    if p.event_shape != q.event_shape:
+        raise ValueError("KL-divergence between two Multivariate Normals with\
+                          different event shapes cannot be computed")
+
+    term1 = _batch_diag(q.scale_tril).log().sum(-1) - _batch_diag(p.scale_tril).log().sum(-1)
+
+    term2 = _batch_trace(_batch_mm(_batch_inverse(q.covariance_matrix), p.covariance_matrix))
body:
In my opinion, it is better to use `q.scale_tril` to calculate things related to the inverse of a positive definite matrix.

In this case, we can simplify the computation by using properties of trace:
$ tr( inv(LLt) @ SSt) = tr( inv(Lt) inv(L) S St) = tr( inv(L) S St inv(Lt)) $
So this trace term can be calculated from inv(L) S by squaring it and take sum.
